content.question: Which of the following best helps explain why the first ionization energy of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that of <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The electronegativity of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than that of <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The atomic radius of the <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom is less than that of the <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom.

The valence electron of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> experiences a lower effective nuclear charge than the valence electrons of <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The nucleus of the <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has fewer neutrons, on average, than the nucleus of the <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom has.

content.answer: The valence electron of <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> experiences a lower effective nuclear charge than the valence electrons of <math alttext="C a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
